verses.text: Behold, a day is coming for the LORD, when the spoil taken from you will be divided in your midst.
verses.comment: The prophecy begins with an announcement of a decisive day for the LORD—a motif which repeats often in prophetic literature, symbolizing both judgment and restoration.

verses.text: For I will gather all the nations against Jerusalem for battle; the city shall be taken, the houses plundered, and the women violated. Half of the city shall go into exile, but the rest of the people shall not be cut off from the city.
verses.comment: This verse depicts a time of great tribulation for Jerusalem, yet indicates that a remnant will remain. Links to prophecies about the suffering and restoration of Israel.

verses.text: Then the LORD will go out and fight against those nations, as he fights on the day of battle.
verses.comment: God himself intervenes in the battle, a clear sign of His sovereignty and deliverance—a theme echoed in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: On that day his feet shall stand on the Mount of Olives, which faces Jerusalem on the east; and the Mount of Olives shall be split in two from east to west by a very great valley, so that half of the mountain shall move north and half south.
verses.comment: The precise detail of the LORD standing on the Mount of Olives has strong Christological significance, as Jesus ascended from and promised return to this location (Acts 1). A physical and spiritual fulfillment is anticipated here.

verses.text: And you shall flee through my valley of mountains, for the valley of the mountains shall reach to Azal. You shall flee as you fled from the earthquake in the days of Uzziah king of Judah. Then the LORD my God will come, and all the holy ones with him.
verses.comment: The coming of the LORD with 'holy ones' is often seen as a reference to angelic hosts—or saints—accompanying the divine presence, tied to apocalyptic imagery in the New Testament.

verses.text: On that day, there shall be no light, cold, or frost.
verses.comment: This phenomenon indicates a cosmic upheaval, echoing day-of-the-LORD motifs found throughout prophetic and apocalyptic literature.

verses.text: It will be a unique day, known to the LORD, not day or night, but at evening there will be light.
verses.comment: A supernatural day, only known fully by the LORD, with unusual manifestation of light, pointing to divine presence and revelation. This parallels the promise of eternal light in the new creation.

verses.text: And on that day, living waters shall flow out from Jerusalem, half of them toward the eastern sea and half toward the western sea. It shall be so in summer and in winter.
verses.comment: Living waters symbolize spiritual renewal and the life-giving presence of God, as seen in Ezekiel's vision and Jesus’ declaration (John 7). The image also signifies the universality of grace flowing from God’s city.

verses.text: And the LORD will be King over all the earth. On that day, the LORD will be one and his name one.
verses.comment: A pronouncement of the LORD’s universal kingship, affirming monotheism ('one') and ultimate sovereignty—a repeated theme in both Old and New Testaments, culminating in Christ’s eternal reign.

verses.text: All the land shall be turned into a plain from Geba to Rimmon south of Jerusalem. But Jerusalem shall be elevated and remain in its place, from the Gate of Benjamin to the site of the First Gate, to the Corner Gate, and from the Tower of Hananel to the king’s winepresses.
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s physical exaltation emphasizes its centrality in salvation history. The restoration and expansion of the city foreshadow the establishment of a chosen kingdom and worship center.

verses.text: And people will live in it, and there shall be no more curse. Jerusalem shall dwell in security.
verses.comment: The removal of the curse and promise of lasting security points toward final redemption—a motif fulfilled in the New Jerusalem (Rev. 21–22).

verses.text: And this shall be the plague with which the LORD will strike all the peoples who wage war against Jerusalem: their flesh will rot while they stand on their feet, their eyes will rot in their sockets, and their tongues will rot in their mouths.
verses.comment: A graphic depiction of judgment upon God's adversaries, highlighting both the seriousness of opposition to God and His power to deliver His people.

verses.text: On that day, a great panic from the LORD will fall on them, so that each will seize the hand of another, and raise his hand against his neighbor.
verses.comment: Divine confusion leads to self-destruction among the enemies—a recurring means by which God intervenes for His people in battles.

verses.text: Even Judah will fight at Jerusalem, and the wealth of all the surrounding nations shall be gathered, gold, silver, and apparel in great abundance.
verses.comment: Judah’s involvement further unites the people around Jerusalem, and the collection of wealth indicates restoration and glory following tribulation.

verses.text: And a plague like this shall strike the horses, the mules, the camels, the donkeys, and every beast that will be in those camps.
verses.comment: God’s judgment extends not merely to people but to their possessions—demonstrating absolute sovereignty over creation.

verses.text: Then everyone who remains of all the nations that came against Jerusalem shall go up year after year to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, and to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: A striking image of worldwide pilgrimage and worship. Even Gentiles are drawn in, reflecting the inclusive nature of redemption and the unity of all nations in worship—a fulfillment of God’s universal plan.

verses.text: And if any of the families of the earth do not go up to Jerusalem to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, none of them shall have rain.
verses.comment: Blessing and spiritual provision are conditional upon recognition of and worship to the LORD, emphasizing the necessity of true worship and spiritual obedience.

verses.text: And if the family of Egypt does not go up and enter in, then there shall be no rain for them. This shall be the plague with which the LORD afflicts the nations who do not go up to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: Egypt, once a source of Israel’s suffering, is specifically called out to highlight God’s rule over all nations and His willingness to offer inclusion through worship.

verses.text: This shall be the punishment of Egypt and the punishment of all the nations that do not go up to celebrate the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: Participation in worship is demanded for blessing, with non-participation resulting in discipline. The necessity of visible, unified worship points to the enduring centrality of Jerusalem and the Temple in salvation history.

verses.text: On that day, 'Holy to the LORD' shall be inscribed on the bells of the horses. And the cooking pots in the LORD’s house shall be as sacred as the bowls before the altar.
verses.comment: All creation, even everyday objects, are consecrated for sacred use—anticipating a time when all things can be offered to God and serve His worship. Here, the distinction between sacred and secular is dissolved in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: And every pot in Jerusalem and Judah shall be holy to the LORD of hosts, so that all who offer sacrifice may come and use them to boil their meat. And on that day no merchant shall be in the house of the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Universal holiness and the purification of worship are established. The removal of merchants from the LORD’s house echoes Christ’s cleansing of the Temple (John 2:16), pointing to exclusive, undivided worship ordered by God.
